list.title: Question 1
list.content: The ocean pressure, $P$, under sea level can be modelled by the function $$ P(D) = \dfrac{D}{10}+1 $$ where $D$ is the distance in metres below sea level and $P$ is measured in atmospheres. A submarine cruising near the surface is submerged according to the function $$ D(t) = 10+5t $$ where $t$ is measured in minutes and $D$ is the distance the submarine is below sea level, measured in metres. - Find the composite function $P\circ D$ and explain what it means in the context of this question[3] - Find and interpret $(P\circ D)(10)$.[2]
list.markScheme:
- The composite function can be expressed as

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (P\circ D) (t) &= P(D(t)) \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  &= P(10+5t)\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &= \dfrac{10+5t}{10}+1 \rule[-4.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &\hspace{0.28em}\answer{= 2+\dfrac{t}{2}}\rule[-5.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  This composite function represents the ocean pressure (in atmospheres) outside the submarine at time t minutes.
- Substituting $t=10$ in (1), we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (P\circ D)(10)&=2+\dfrac{10}{2}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  &\hspace{0.28em}\answer{=7}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  This result means that after 10 minutes, the ocean pressure outside the submarine is 7 atmospheres.

list.title: Question 2
list.content: The temperature, $T$, measured in degrees Celsius, above ground level in Bagan, Myanmar, can be modelled by the function $$ T(H)=37-\dfrac{H}{160} $$ where $H$ is the height above ground, measured in metres. The height, $H$, of a hot air balloon carrying tourists on a particular day in Bagan is given by the function $$ H(t) = 40+10t $$ where $H$ is in metres, and $t$ is the time in minutes after reaching cruising height. - Find the composite function $T\circ H$ and explain what it means in the context of this question.[3] - Find $(T\circ H)(36)$ and explain what it means in the context of this question.[2]
list.markScheme:
- The composite function can be expressed as

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (T\circ H) (t) &= T(H(t)) \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  &= T(40+10t)\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &= 37-\dfrac{40+10t}{160} \rule[-4.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &= 37-\dfrac{40}{160}-\dfrac{10t}{160} \rule[-4.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &\hspace{0.28em}\answer{= 36.75-\dfrac{t}{16}}\rule[-5.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  This composite function represents the temperature outside the hot air balloon after $t$ minutes of the balloon cruising.
- Substituting $t=36$ in (1), we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (T\circ H)(36)&=36.75-\dfrac{36}{16}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  &\hspace{0.28em}\answer{=34.5}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  It means that after 36 minutes of the hot air balloon cruising, the temperature outside the balloon is 34.5 degrees Celcius.

list.title: Question 3
list.content: The subscription fee for an online project management software by AB-Tech is $\$ 40$ per month. If the customer buys for a whole year in advance, a discount of $\$130$ is applied. This can be modelled by the following function, $P(n)$, which gives the total cost when paying annually for the subscription. $$ P(n) = 40n - 130,\quad n\geq 12 $$ where $n$ is the number months. - Find the total cost of buying a subscription for $2$ years. [2] - Find $P^{-1}(1790)$. [2] The subscription price for a different online project management tool by YZ-tech is $\$35$ per month, however customers can only purchase annually in advance, and there are no discounts. The total subscription cost of YZ-tech's software is less than AB-tech's software when $n>k$ . - Find the minimum value of $k$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Substituting $n=24$ into the $P(n)$ function, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  P(n) &=40n-130\\[6pt]
  P(24) &= 40(24)-130 \\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.5em}\answer{=\$ 830}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let's denote $P(n)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $n$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= 40n-130 \\[6pt]
  n&=40y-130\\[6pt]
  40y&=n+130\\[6pt]
  y&=\dfrac{n+130}{40}\\[6pt]
  P^{-1}(n) &= \dfrac{n+130}{40}\end{aligned}
  $$

  We can now find
$P^{-1}(1790)$ as follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  P^{-1}(1790)&=\dfrac{1790+130}{40}\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{-3.5em}\answer{P^{-1}(1790)=48 \text{ months}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- For AB-tech's software we we were given the pricing function

  $$
  P(n)=40n-130
  
  $$

  For YZ-tech, we can define the function, $S(n)$, to
represent the subscription price for their software

  $$
  S(n)=35n
  $$

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2b908e8c-786e-4fec-844c-19b9653ea308/images/7386b1f2-6825-49b7-88df-da2a1e5501e7/7402d7e1fc9d51e4e9f6b0f5ea74f75143d1438e.svg)


  From the graph, $S(n) < P(n)$ for $n>26$.
  The price of YZ-tech's software is less than AB-tech's when $n>26$.
  Therefore,  $\answer{k=26}$

list.title: Question 4
list.content: A tyre manufacturing company has found that the number of tyres it produces, $N$, can be modelled by the function $$ N(t)=3t-9 $$ where $t$ is the number of hours the factory operates per day, with a minimum of 3 hours. The profit the company makes, $P$, in dollars, depends on the number of tyres produced, and is modelled by the function $$ P(N)=60N-850 $$ where $N$ is the number of tyres produced. - Find the company's profit or loss if it operates for $6$ hours per day.[2] - Find the company's profit in terms of the hours of operation per day, $t$.[2] - Determine the number of hours the company needs to operate the factory per day in order to earn a positive profit. Give your answer to the nearest hour.[2]
list.markScheme:
- Substituting $t=6$ in $N(t)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  N(6) &= 3(6)-9 = 9\\
  \text{Thus, the profit is given by P(9)}
  P(9) &= 60(9)-850 = -310\end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore, operating $6$
hours a day, the company has a loss:
$\answer{\text{-310}}$
- The profit in terms of the hours of operation per day can be found
by the composite function $P\circ N$. Hence, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (P\circ N)(t) &= P(N(t)) \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  &= P(3t-9) \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{7mm}\\
  &= 60(3t-9)-850\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{7mm}\\
  &\hspace{-4.55em}\answer{(P\circ N)(t) = 180\hspace{0.05em}t-1390}\qref{(1)}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{4mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The company has a positive profit if (1) is greater than 0. Hence

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (P\circ N)(t) &>0\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  180t-1390 &> 0 \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  t &> \dfrac{1390}{180} \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  t &> 7.72.\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore, the
factory needs to operate
$\answer{8}$
hours per day in order for the company to earn a positive profit.

list.title: Question 5
list.content: The number of fish in a lake, $f$, is given by the function $$ \begin{align*} f(x) &= 450\,e^{-0.1x}+50 \end{align*} $$ Where $x$ is the approximate concentration of algae in the lake, measured in parts per billion (ppb) and $x \geq 0$. - Determine the range of $f$. [2] - Find an expression for $f^{-1}(x)$. [3] The lake is considered "healthy" if there are at least $430$ fish at any given time. - Calculate the range of algae concentrations for which the lake can be considered healthy. [3]

list.title: Question 6
list.content: The circumference, $C$, of a given circle can be represented by the function $$ \begin{aligned} C(A) &= 2\pi\sqrt{\dfrac{A}{\pi}}, \hspace{0.5em} A \geq 0,\end{aligned} $$ where $A$ is the area of the circle. The graph of the function $C$, for $0 \leq A \leq 24$, is shown below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0b7df521-ef1b-4c8a-87b1-32e564791325/images/ce866e5f-cd7d-44ed-9b43-19469f4d4737/3388e210bb4d6f02426816cb2651396f2822c4c1.svg) - Find the value of $C(24)$. [1] - On the grid above, draw the graph of the inverse function, $C^{-1}$. [3] - In the context of the question, explain the meaning of $C^{-1}(2\pi) = \pi$. [1]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $C(A)$ for $A = 24$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  C(A) &= 2\pi\sqrt{\dfrac{24}{\pi}} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 17.4}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we draw the graph of the inverse function, $C^{-1}$, on the grid
below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0b7df521-ef1b-4c8a-87b1-32e564791325/images/3b17f6c6-ed96-4a9a-b40e-195870b66409/fae26733051cc1a7c15c3478abb0d0697e69d7fa.svg)


- $\answer{\text{For a given circle, when the circumference is \(2\pi\), the area is \(\pi\)}}$

list.title: Question 7
list.content: A town is planning to construct a jogging path in a grass field $170$ m long and $70$ m wide. The path is to be the shape of a rectangle with two semicircles of radius $x$, as shown in the diagram. The sides of the rectangle connecting the circles are to be $100$ m long. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3b56cb39-04a1-4c8f-b16c-f5a5245daaaa/images/d44b0d34-7ffb-4949-8d1e-a3dbe9c818bb/22448faee8b9c6574b3fdefa8505f67030a94583.svg) - Write down a function, $P$, (in metres) for the perimeter of the jogging path, in terms of the radius, $x$.[1] - Determine the domain and range of $P$, taking into consideration the dimensions of the grass field.[2] - Find an equation for the inverse function $P^{-1}(x)$. Express your answer in the form $P^{-1}(x)=mx+c$.[2] The designers of the path are deciding whether the total length of the path should be $300$ m, $400$ m, or $500$ m. The designers want to maximise the perimeter of the path, but fit the path in the grass field. - Determine which length is most suitable, given the dimensions of the grass field.[2]
list.markScheme:
- The perimeter for the path is the sum of the two straight sides
connecting the circles and the perimeter of a complete circle of
radius $x$. We get

  $$
  \answer{P(x) = 200+2\pi x}
  $$

- The length of the path will be $100+2x$ and its width $2x$.
Therefore we require $100+2x\leq 170$ and $2x\leq 70$. Hence

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{\text{Domain: } 0\leq x \leq 35.}\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  For
the range, the function $P(x)$ is increasing and $P(0)=200$ and
$P(35)=200+70\pi$. We get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{\text{Range: } 200\leq P(x) \leq 200+70\pi.}\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- Let's denote $P(x)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $x$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= 200+2\pi x\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  x &= 200+2\pi y\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  y &= \dfrac{x-200}{2\pi}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\ 
  &\hspace{-3.2em}\answer{P^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{1}{2\pi}x - \dfrac{100}{\pi}}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- For each of the proposed perimeters $P$, we can find the radius
value $x$ as $x=P^{-1}(P)$, then the length and width of the running
track can be calculated, as shown in the following table.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3b56cb39-04a1-4c8f-b16c-f5a5245daaaa/images/a51374e0-38d2-4194-a69c-09dd7705203d/8985560368df68be350c8eca5afbe5b19a733963.svg)


  From the table, we can see that the largest perimeter of the options
that still fit inside the grass field dimensions is

  $$
  \answer{P=400\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}.}
  $$

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Harry is planning on constructing a glass window in one of the outer walls of his house. The dimensions of the wall space available are 2m x 2m. Harry wants the window to be in the shape shown in the diagram below. The bottom section is a rectangle and the top part is a semicircle of radius $x$ m. Harry wants the height of the rectangle to be fixed at 1 m. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3b6eacbd-eff9-4731-9da7-653273efcc3e/images/2857a1b4-2a9c-44c8-8215-923593110245/4b81f49038bd3a70fed3ed55e752da67f426bdf2.svg) - Write down a function $P$ (in metres) for the perimeter of the window in terms of the radius, $x$.[1] - Determine the domain and range of $P$, taking into consideration the dimensions of the available wall.[2] - Find an equation for the inverse function $P^{-1}(x)$. Express your answer in the form $P^{-1}(x)=mx+c$.[2] Harry wants to maximise the size of the window, however the window frame that covers the perimeter of the window can only be 5, 6, or 7 metres long, due to manufacturing restrictions. - Determine which perimeter length is the best option for Harry.[2]
list.markScheme:
- The perimeter for the window is the sum of the three sides of the
rectangle and the semicircle, thus we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  P(x) &= \text{Rectangle width}+2\times\text{Rectangle height}+\text{Semicircle} \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  &= 2x+2(1)+\dfrac{\cancel{2}\pi x}{\cancel{2}} \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{8mm}\\
  &\hspace{-2.15em}\answer{P(x) = 2+(2+\pi)x}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The width of the window will be $2x$ and the height $1+x$.
Therefore, we require $2x\leq 2$ and $1+x\leq 2$.
Hence

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{\text{Domain: } 0\leq x \leq 1.}\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Now
for the range, the function $P(x)$ is increasing and $P(0)=2$ and
$P(1)=4+\pi$. Therefore,

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{\text{Range: } 2\leq P(x) \leq 4+\pi.}\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- Let's denote $P(x)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $x$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= 2+(2+\pi)x\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  x &= 2+(2+\pi)y\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  y &= \dfrac{x-2}{(2+\pi)}\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\ 
  &\hspace{-3.2em}\answer{P^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x-2}{(2+\pi)}}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{6mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- For each of the proposed perimeters $P$, we can find the radius
value $x$ as $x=P^{-1}(P)$, then the length and width of the window
can be calculated, as shown in the following table
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3b6eacbd-eff9-4731-9da7-653273efcc3e/images/d54f8441-1a6b-4d76-8a64-a7b4d6867247/95900dceeb57876cf3bec3ce67dc138811471933.svg)


  From the table, we can see that the perimeter that maximizes the
dimension of the window that fits in the wall is

  $$
  \answer{P=7\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}.}
  $$

list.title: Question 9
list.content: The radius of a cylindrical container with height $x$ cm is $$ \begin{aligned} r(x) = \dfrac{56}{x},\qquad 4\leq x\leq 16\end{aligned} $$ - Find the range of $r$.[3] The function $r^{-1}$ is the inverse function of $r$. - - Find $r^{-1}(8)$. - Interpret the answer to part (b) (i) in context. - Find the range of $r^{-1}$.[4]
list.markScheme:
- A sketch of $r(x)$ shows that the minimum value is found where $x=16$ and the maximum value is found where $x=4$.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/47ec87ad-d03d-40ae-b070-86ca7d589f8a/images/5e3319c6-2a5b-4f5e-9751-0736b3e580f0/AI1002a.PNG)


  Evaluating $r$ at the endpoints of its domain, we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  r(4) &= \dfrac{56}{4} = 14 \\[11pt]
  r(16) &= \dfrac{56}{16} = 3.5
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Therefore the range of $r$ is $\answer{3.5 \leq r \leq 14}$
- 
  - Let $r^{-1}(8)=a$. This implies that $r(a)=8$.

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \dfrac{56}{a} &= 8 \\[11pt]
    a &= \dfrac{56}{8} \\[11pt]
    a &= 7
    \end{align*}
    $$

    $r(7)=8$ and therefore $\answer{r^{-1}(8) = 7}$
  - When the radius of the container is $8\,$cm the height is $7\,$cm
  - Using the definition of a function inverse, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \text{range of $r^{-1}$} &= \text{domain of $r$}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore the range of $r^{-1}$ is $\answer{4 \leq r^{-1} \leq 16}$

list.title: Question 10
list.content: A conical funnel is used to add water to a scientific experiment. The funnel initially contains 3 L of water, and the water flows out of the funnel at a rate of 40 mL per minute. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/56f5072c-2f53-49d8-b6ea-7999bc16ba97/images/ed36937a-80cb-4a49-9a96-eaeafce08153/8c377cf98298a7a684cfd677cfc233747ca8bc06.svg) - Determine a function for the volume $V$ (in millilitres) of water remaining in the funnel after $t$ minutes.[2] - If there is $V$ mL of water in the funnel, show that the height of the water can be expressed as $h(V)=3 \sqrt[3]{\dfrac{V}{\pi}}$ cm. [4] - Find the composite function $h\circ V$, and interpret what it means in the context of this question.[3] - Find $(h\circ V)(15)$ and explain what it means in the context of this question.[2]
list.markScheme:
- The volume of water starts at 3000 mL and decreases 40 mL per
minute. Hence, we get

  $$
  \answer{V(t)=3\hspace{0.15em}000-40\hspace{0.1em}t}
  $$

- Let's consider a cross-sectional view of the right part of the
funnel, as shown in the figure
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/56f5072c-2f53-49d8-b6ea-7999bc16ba97/images/8916d387-34e1-40df-8464-c10b8811efef/1fa1545b27c671db53373226d01df2aa7fd58824.svg)


  From the diagram, using similarity, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{r}{10} &= \dfrac{h}{30} \\[7pt]
  r &= \dfrac{h}{3}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using the volume formula for a cone, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  V &= \dfrac{1}{3} \pi \left(\dfrac{h}{3}\right)^2 h\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{10mm} \\
  V &= \dfrac{1}{27} \pi h^3 \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{10mm}\\
  h^3 &= 27\dfrac{V}{\pi} \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{10mm}\\
  &\hspace{-0.3em}\answer{h = 3 \sqrt[3]{\dfrac{V}{\pi}}}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{6.5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The composite function can be expressed as

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (h\circ V)(t) &= h(3000-40\hspace{0.1em}t) \\[7pt]
  &\hspace{0.3em}\answer{= 3 \sqrt[3]{\dfrac{3000-40\hspace{0.1em}t}{\pi}}}\qref{(1)}\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  This composite function represents the height of water remaining in the funnel after $t$ minutes.
- Evaluating $t=15$ in (1), we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (h\circ V))(15) &= 3 \sqrt[3]{\dfrac{3000-40\hspace{0.1em}(15)}{\pi}} \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{0.3em}\answer{\approx 27.4\hspace{0.25em}\text{cm}}\hspace{4em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{\text{It means that after 15 minutes the height of water remaining in the funnel is $27.4$ cm.}}
  $$

list.title: Question 11
list.content: Consider the following composite shape, consisting of a rectangle of length 50 cm and varying width $x$ cm, and three-quarter circle with its center at a vertex of the rectangle and radius equal to the rectangle width, $x$ cm. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6067168f-a8d6-43d6-af12-c8d85c12a9bc/images/4f9c52d8-322c-471b-bd07-d4575afde2e5/9ed23f8a95d65fb8498a74d7b3a0d8921a8b6a79.svg) - Determine a function, $L$, in terms of $x$, for the total length of line seen in the diagram. This consists of both the perimeter of the rectangle and circumference of the three-quarter circle.[2] Constraints are placed on the dimensions of the composite shape. The total length and width of the composite shape cannot exceed $100$ cm and $80$ cm respectively. - Determine the domain and range of $L$, taking into consideration these constraints.[2] - Find an equation for the inverse function $L^{-1}(x)$. Express your answer in the form $L^{-1}(x)=mx+c$.[2] Suppose $L$ can only be in multiples of $100$ cm (i.e., $100$ cm, $200$ cm, $300$ cm, ...). - Determine the maximum length of $L$ that satisfies the constraints.[2]
list.markScheme:
- The total length of the line, $L$, is the sum of the rectangle
perimeter and $3/4$'s of the circumference of a circle of radius
$x$. We get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  L(x) &= 2(50) + 2x + \dfrac{3}{4}(2\pi x) \\[7pt]
  &= 100 + 2x + \dfrac{3\pi x}{2} \\[7pt]
  &\hspace{-2.2em}\answer{L(x) = 100+\left(2+\dfrac{3\pi}{2}\right)x}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Since the total length cannot exceed
$100$ cm, we get $50+x\leq 100$. Similarly,
the total width cannot exceed $80$ cm,
therefore $2x\leq 80$. Hence

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{\text{Domain: } 0 < x \leq 40.}\end{aligned}
  $$

  The
function $L(x)$ is increasing, $L(0)=100$, and $L(40)=180+60\pi$.
Hence

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{\text{Range: } 100 < L(x) \leq 180+60\pi.}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let's denote $L(x)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $x$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= 100+\left(2+\dfrac{3\pi}{2}\right)x\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  x &= 100+\left(2+\dfrac{3\pi}{2}\right)y\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  y &= \dfrac{2(x-100)}{4+3\pi}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\ 
  &\hspace{-3.2em}\answer{L^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{2x}{4+3\pi}-\dfrac{200}{4+3\pi}}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- For each of the possible values of $L$, we can find the radius value
$x$ since $x=L^{-1}(L)$. The length and width of the composite shape
can then be calculated and compared against the constraints, as
shown in the following table.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6067168f-a8d6-43d6-af12-c8d85c12a9bc/images/0fb0cecd-64f1-4b3c-8840-8c94b4968b3a/881fb34d4c0132d6f520788601f45a7a6a476a82.svg)


  From the table, we can see that the largest line length of the
options that satisfies the constraints is

  $$
  \answer{L=300\hspace{0.25em}\text{cm}.}
  $$

list.title: Question 12
list.content: The perimeter, $P$, of a given rectangle can be represented by the function $$ \begin{aligned} P(A) &= 6\sqrt{\dfrac{A}{2}}, \hspace{0.5em} A \geq 0,\end{aligned} $$ where $A$ is the area of the rectangle. The graph of the function $P$, for $0 \leq A \leq 24$, is shown below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ab39cb62-6642-463f-8d55-b3b4e61d9fc1/images/d77d8ca4-60bf-47df-b71e-f5b1a82ac6ef/13be64c3a363091e834dcc3848fda5575c4c9b07.svg) - Find the value of $P(24)$. [1] - On the grid above, draw the graph of the inverse function, $P^{-1}$. [3] - In the context of the question, explain the meaning of $P^{-1}(12) = 8$. [1]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $P(A)$ for $A = 24$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  P(A) &= 6\sqrt{\dfrac{24}{2}} \hspace{0.6em}  \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 20.8}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we draw the graph of the inverse function, $P^{-1}$, on the grid
below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ab39cb62-6642-463f-8d55-b3b4e61d9fc1/images/ff3fed55-9366-4196-a9da-e2951114048a/0d0a8ad4bbd75e6a6d48466c8f25e5a869af08fe.svg)


- $\answer{\text{For a given rectangle, when the perimeter is \(12\), the area is \(8\)}}$

list.title: Question 13
list.content: The area, $A$, of a given square can be represented by the function $$ \begin{aligned} A(P) &= \dfrac{P^2}{16}, \hspace{0.5em} P \geq 0,\end{aligned} $$ where $P$ is the perimeter of the square. The graph of the function $A$, for $0 \leq P \leq 20$, is shown below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d67d010e-f96a-4959-94d7-dd830ba69f41/images/db5dae3b-4d37-46d8-a488-586d1cdc2312/8c2c1a298c1b79e92e64f94fe2b4a4d452e488ad.svg) - Find the value of $A(20)$. [1] - On the grid above, draw the graph of the inverse function, $A^{-1}$. [3] - In the context of the question, explain the meaning of $A^{-1}(4) = 8$. [1]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $A(P)$ for $P = 20$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  A(P) &= \dfrac{20^2}{16} \hspace{1.7em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 25}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we draw the graph of the inverse function, $A^{-1}$, on the grid
below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d67d010e-f96a-4959-94d7-dd830ba69f41/images/8288a0de-f259-43ef-a694-da2f13679dc3/508588bd8662a40575516587374d1e3379be6249.svg)


- $\answer{\text{For a given square, when the area is \(4\), the perimeter is \(8\)}}$

list.title: Question 15
list.content: A cable making machine in a factory produces 5 metres of cable every 3 minutes. After 4 hours of continuous use, the machine requires 48 minutes of preventative maintenance. Apart from this preventative maintenance, the machine works continuously without interruption. - Determine the function, $L$, that represents the length of cable produced in terms of time, $t$, measured in days.[2] The company sells the cable it produces and has found that the income (in dollars) from selling $L$ metres of cable can be modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} I(L) = (3-\sqrt{7})L-500\\ \end{aligned} $$ - Determine a function for income, $I$, in terms of time, $t$, in days. [3] The company is considering an investment in a new machine that produces 6 metres of cable every 3 minutes and needs 60 minutes of preventive maintenance for every 7 hours of use. - Show that the income function for this new machine, in terms of the number of days, $t$, can be expressed as.[3] $$ \begin{aligned} I_2(t) = (3-\sqrt{7})(2\hspace{0.1em}520\hspace{0.1em}t)-500\\ \end{aligned} $$ - Determine a function, $D$, to model the difference in incomes between the two machines, in terms of the number of days, $t$.[3] The company decides to purchase the new machine only if it can recover the cost of the machine through the difference in incomes over six month period (assume 180 days). - Find the highest amount the company will be willing to pay for the new machine, rounded to the nearest dollar.[2]
list.markScheme:
- A complete cycle operation-maintenance of the machine takes 4 hours
and 48 minutes, and thus, in one day, there are 5 complete
operation-maintenance cycles.
  Therefore the amount of cable produced in $t$ days can be expressed
as

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  L(t) &= \text{Amount produced by 5 operation-maintenance cycles}\times t\hspace{0.25em}\text{days} \rule[-4mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  &= \left(\dfrac{5\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}}{3\hspace{0.25em}\cancel{\text{min}}}\right)\left(\dfrac{60\hspace{0.25em}\cancel{\text{min}}}{1\hspace{0.25em}\cancel{\text{hr}}}\right)\left(\dfrac{4\hspace{0.25em}\cancel{\text{hr}}}{1\hspace{0.25em}\cancel{\text{cycle}}}\right)\left(\dfrac{5\hspace{0.25em}\cancel{\text{cycles}}}{1\hspace{0.25em}\cancel{\text{day}}}\right)t\hspace{0.25em}\cancel{\text{days}}\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{10mm}\\
  &\hspace{-1.8em}\answer{L(t)=2\hspace{0.15em}000 \hspace{0.1em}t}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{6mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We can find an expression for the composite function $I\circ L$ as
follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  I \circ L(t) &= I(L(t)) \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  &= I(2\hspace{0.15em}000 \hspace{0.1em}t)\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{7mm}\\
  &\hspace{-3.25em}\answer{I \circ L(t)= (3-\sqrt{7})(2\hspace{0.15em}000)\hspace{0.05em}t-500}\qref{(1)}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{4mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- This machine can complete 3 operation-maintenance cycles per day,
and so the amount of cable it produces is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  L_2(t) &= \text{Amount produced by 3 operation-maintenance cycles}\times t\hspace{0.25em}\text{days} \rule[-4mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  &= \left(\dfrac{6\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}}{3\hspace{0.25em}\cancel{\text{min}}}\right)\left(\dfrac{60\hspace{0.25em}\cancel{\text{min}}}{1\hspace{0.25em}\cancel{\text{hr}}}\right)\left(\dfrac{7\hspace{0.25em}\cancel{\text{hr}}}{1\hspace{0.25em}\cancel{\text{cycle}}}\right)\left(\dfrac{3\hspace{0.25em}\cancel{\text{cycles}}}{1\hspace{0.25em}\cancel{\text{day}}}\right)t\hspace{0.25em}\cancel{\text{days}}\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{10mm}\\
  &\hspace{-1.8em}\answer{L_2(t)=2\hspace{0.15em}520 \hspace{0.1em}t}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{6mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Now we find the composite $I\circ L_2$:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (I \circ L_2)(t) &= I(L_2(t)) \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  &= I(2\hspace{0.15em}520 \hspace{0.1em}t)\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{7mm}\\
  &\hspace{-4.55em}\answer{(I \circ L_2)(t) = (3-\sqrt{7})(2\hspace{0.15em}520)\hspace{0.05em}t-500}\qref{(2)} \rule[0mm]{0pt}{4mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The difference in incomes between the two machines is the difference
(2)$-$(1). We get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  D(t) &= \big[(3-\sqrt{7})(2\hspace{0.15em}520)\hspace{0.05em}t-\cancel{500}\big] - \big[(3-\sqrt{7})(2\hspace{0.15em}000)\hspace{0.05em}t-\cancel{500}\big]\\[6pt]
  &= (3-\sqrt{7}) (2\hspace{0.15em}520-2\hspace{0.15em}000)\hspace{0.05em}t\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{-1.97em}\answer{D(t)= (3-\sqrt{7})(520)\hspace{0.05em}t} \qref{(3)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Substituting $t=180$ in (3), we get

  $$
  \hspace{1.65em}D(180) = (3-\sqrt{7})(520)(180) \approx 33\hspace{0.07em}157.68
  $$

  The company is willing to pay
$\answer{\hspace{0.07em}33\hspace{0.15em}158}$
for the new machine.

list.title: Question 16
list.content: A function is defined by $g(x)=3-\dfrac{12}{x+3}$ for $-9\leq x\leq 9$, $x\neq -3$ - Find the range of $g$. [3] - Find the value of $g^{-1}(0)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- The graph of $g(x)=3-\dfrac{12}{x+3}$ is plotted below.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/616164a4-faa5-4676-9f3c-4769c3d41be8/images/23cbcbe8-15fc-47be-83cd-0d50dcfbc06b/AI881a.PNG)


  From the graph, the range of $g$ is $\answer{(-\infty,2]\cup[5,\infty)]}$
- $g^{-1}(0)$ corresponds to the value of $x$ when $g(x)=0$.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/616164a4-faa5-4676-9f3c-4769c3d41be8/images/47112aa7-51a3-49b0-9ae0-889a5f78ea51/AI881b.PNG)


  From the graph, $g(x)=0$ when $x=1$. Hence,

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{g^{-1}(0)=1}
  \end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 17
list.content: A function is defined by $f(x)=\dfrac{\sqrt{x+1}}{x^2-4}$, for the domain $-1\leq x\leq 5$, $x\neq 2$ - Find the range of $f$. [4] - Find the value of $f^{-1}\left(\dfrac{2}{5}\right)$. [2]

list.title: Question 18
list.content: A function is defined by $f(x)=\sqrt{x+5}$, $x\geq -5$ - Determine the domain and range of $f$. [3] - Find the value of $f^{-1}(\sqrt{6})$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- The graph of $f(x)=\sqrt{x+5}$ is plotted below.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8ae200fc-c8c2-45b4-aa13-f0e9f279cb9a/images/881074fb-10d0-4145-9bf1-ee5c090fa571/1805e337e073512237286acb5583906bdf31bb84.svg)


  From the graph, the domain of $f$ is

  $$
  \answer{[-5,\infty)}
  $$

  and the range of $f$ is

  $$
  \answer{[0,\infty)}
  $$

- $f^{-1}(\sqrt{6})$ corresponds to the value of $x$ when
$f(x)=\sqrt{6}$.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8ae200fc-c8c2-45b4-aa13-f0e9f279cb9a/images/5e47c30a-f23c-47d5-b947-709f7668078d/7c19742e74bbe79b3eeb3b8509335ac2df5057a0.svg)


  From the graph, $f(x)=\sqrt{6}$ when $x=1$. Hence,

  $$
  \answer{f^{-1}(\sqrt{6})=1}
  $$

list.title: Question 19
list.content: The function $f$ is defined by $f(x) = \dfrac{7x-24}{x-2}$, for $-3 \leq x \leq 12$, $x \neq 2$. - Find the range of $f$. [3] - Find an expression for the inverse function $f^{-1}(x)$. [3] - Write down the range of $f^{-1}$. [1]
list.markScheme:
- If we draw the graph of $f$, by using G.D.C., we
have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8f054f1a-9ea4-4053-a5d1-6fa515e9906d/images/1a167d6a-7e1e-416a-b9c6-b49067e30e6a/6790d3e3a83e5ec16eb602a4d64032370f792ab9.svg)


  Hence, using the $y$-coordinates of A and B, we find
$\answer{(-\infty, 6] \cup [9, \infty)}$
- If we solve the equation $x = (f\circ f^{-1})(x)$ for
$y = f^{-1}(x)$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x &= f(f^{-1}(x)) \\[12pt]
  x &= f(y) \\[12pt]
  x &= \dfrac{7y-24}{y-2} \\[12pt]
  x(y-2) &= 7y-24 \\[12pt]
  xy-2x &= 7y-24 \\[12pt]
  xy-7y &= 2x-24 \\[12pt]
  y(x-7) &= 2x-24 \\[12pt]
  y &= \dfrac{2x-24}{x-7} \\[12pt]
  &\hspace*{-3.01em}\answer{f^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{2x-24}{x-7}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The range of $f^{-1}(x)$ is equal to the domain of $f(x)$, therefore
the
range of $f^{-1}(x)$ is
$\answer{-3 \leq f^{-1}(x) \leq 12\text{ , } f^{-1}(x) \neq 2}$
